prior_works.title: Approximate Nearest Neighbors: Towards Removing the Curse of Dimensionality
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced LSH and collision-probability based partitioning, which the paper leverages to implement fuzzy-radius ball ranges via collision events, providing the core mechanism to decouple error from ambient dimension.

prior_works.title: Locality-Sensitive Hashing Scheme Based on p-Stable Distributions
prior_works.authors: Mayur Datar, Nicole Immorlica, Piotr Indyk, Vahab Mirrokni
prior_works.role: Technique for Euclidean/ℓp similarity via LSH
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides explicit LSH families for ℓ2/ℓp with calibrated collision probabilities p(r) versus p(cr), enabling the paper’s near-neighbor counting with fuzzy boundaries by turning counts-in-balls into counts-in-buckets with controlled bias.

prior_works.title: Near-Optimal Hashing Algorithms for Approximate Nearest Neighbor in High Dimensions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies near-optimal LSH exponents and analysis of collision decay that the paper exploits to obtain a small (1+o(1)) multiplicative distortion while keeping additive error to n^o(1) through carefully tuned bucketization.

prior_works.title: A Multiplicative Weights Mechanism for Privacy-Preserving Data Analysis
prior_works.role: Baseline DP query-release framework with polynomial additive error
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Represents the non-interactive DP range-counting approach that achieves generality at the cost of additive error polynomial in n; the paper positions its result as improving over this regime by exploiting fuzziness to shrink error.

prior_works.title: Differential Privacy via Wavelet Transforms
prior_works.authors: Xiao Xiao, Guozhang Wang, Johannes Gehrke
prior_works.role: DP range counting with polylogarithmic error in low dimension
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Exemplifies hierarchical/transform-based DP range counting that attains polylog(n) additive error but whose error and complexity blow up exponentially with dimension, forming the second side of the dichotomy that the paper bridges.

prior_works.title: The Geometry of Differential Privacy: The Sparse and Approximate Case
prior_works.authors: Aleksandar Nikolov, Kunal Talwar, Li Zhang
prior_works.role: Lower bounds and geometric viewpoint on DP query error
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides geometric lower bounds and sensitivity tools explaining why high-dimensional range counting suffers exponential-in-d dependence without relaxation; the paper circumvents this via fuzzy boundaries plus hashing-based smoothing.

prior_works.title: A Framework for Similarity Search with Space-Time Tradeoffs using Locality-Sensitive Filtering
prior_works.role: Refined LSH/LSF machinery with tunable collision behavior
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Offers filter-based generalizations of LSH with controllable collision rates, informing the paper’s design of hashing parameters that achieve the stated n^o(1) additive error while keeping privacy noise low and dimension-independent.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution—differentially private approximate near-neighbor counting with arbitrarily small polynomial additive error n^o(1) and a (1+o(1)) multiplicative factor, independent of the ambient dimension—arises by merging hashing-based geometric smoothing with private counting. The LSH lineage (Indyk–Motwani 1998; Datar et al. 2004; Andoni–Indyk 2006) supplies the central algorithmic lever: collision probabilities that sharply separate distances r versus cr enable a principled "fuzzy boundary" for ball ranges. By mapping points into a small number of hash buckets and interpreting collisions as probabilistic membership, the algorithm transforms hard high-dimensional ball counts into low-sensitivity bucket aggregates, where bias is controlled by the p(r) vs. p(cr) gap and variance is handled by repetition and averaging.

On the DP side, classical query-release mechanisms (Hardt–Rothblum 2010) demonstrate generality but incur polynomial-in-n additive error, while hierarchical/transform methods for range counting (Xiao–Wang–Gehrke 2010) achieve polylogarithmic error only in low dimensions, with error that degrades exponentially in d. The geometric lower-bound perspective (Nikolov–Talwar–Zhang 2013) clarifies why such high-dimensional barriers persist without relaxation. The paper sidesteps these barriers by explicitly embracing fuzziness, then using LSH/LSF calibration (Christiani 2017) to tune collision behavior so that each data point affects few buckets (low sensitivity) and counts aggregate with small, dimension-free privacy noise. This synthesis yields the advertised sweet spot: privacy noise that does not grow with dimension, multiplicative distortion near 1, and additive error that is an arbitrarily small power of n, parameterized by the allowed boundary fuzziness.
